text: the sudden disappearance of Air France
flight 447 shocks the world debris shows
the aircraft hit the water with its nose
up an extremely unusual position for a
plane crashing or ditching the ocean
when the plane goes missing it's
travelling through an area infamous for
turbulent skies the Intertropical
Convergence zone investigators rule out
lightly but could turbulence have caused
the plane to crash there's a huge amount
of humidity that builds up in massive
billowing thunderstorms that reach up
even higher than the jet aircraft can
fly nobody wants to fly right through
the middle of a towering Thunder head
climatologist Jeff Weber believes that
weather conditions on the day of the
crash would have made flying extremely
difficult they have this huge convective
cell they had to fly through this
develop dramatically and very quickly
after they had taken off so there was no
way for them to know the intensity of
this convective Tower prior to their
departure it's not a weakening system
it's a strengthening system
by the time the plane hits the weather
system it is a major storm these cloud
tops have reached 45 50 possibly
fifty-five thousand feet
there's probably frozen precipitation
inside this cloud structure as well you
would know you were flying through some
weather there would be a lot of
turbulence in some rare cases extreme
turbulence has brought down planes in
1997 turbulence contributed to the crash
of an Austral Airlines flight in poor
agley with 74 fatalities but the same
have happened to Air France 447
turbulence can knock around an airplane
so much that the movement of the
aircraft exceeds its structural limits
and they have been known to come apart
some wonder if this could have caused
the compression of the wreckage and the
nose up position but on the night flight
447 disappeared 12 other planes flew
through the same weather system with no
safety concerns
